What Is Ivermectin?3/6/2022

Learn more about the drug ivermectin, including the conditions it treats, what side effects it may have, and whether it’s approved to treat COVID-19.

ivermectin, covid-19, covid, side effects, dose, parasitic infectionRead

What Is Ivermectin? </h1><!----><!----><!----><!----><div class="byline"><span class="authors"> By <a href="https://www.webmd.com/evan-starkman" class="person">Evan Starkman</a><!----><!----><!----></span></div></header><!----><div class="med-wrap"><div><span data-chronicle="091e9c5e81e48710" data-e2e="asset-medical-review" data-metrics-module="embd-lnk" data-metrics-module="cwnav-art" data-metrics-sel="li" class="inline-in-art-nav in-article-nav"><!----><h3> In this Article </h3><ul><li><a data-link="1-2" data-metrics-link="cwnav-art_2" href="#091e9c5e8222348c-1-2"> What Conditions Does Ivermectin Treat? </a></li><li><a data-link="1-3" data-metrics-link="cwnav-art_3" href="#091e9c5e8222348c-1-3"> Is Ivermectin Approved to Treat COVID-19? </a></li><li><a data-link="2-4" data-metrics-link="cwnav-art_4" href="#091e9c5e8222348c-2-4"> What Are the Side Effects of Ivermectin? </a></li><li><a data-link="2-5" data-metrics-link="cwnav-art_5" href="#091e9c5e8222348c-2-5"> How Do You Take Ivermectin? </a></li></ul></aside></div><div class="article__body"><div class="article-page active-page" data-page="1"><section><p><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1122/ivermectin+oral/details">Ivermectin</a> is a <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx">medication</a> that treats some parasitic diseases. There are two types of the medication. Doctors prescribe one kind for certain health conditions in people, and veterinarians prescribe another that’s safe only for animals.</p></section><section><h2 id="091e9c5e8222348c-1-2">What Conditions Does Ivermectin Treat?</h2><p>In people, the FDA has approved prescription ivermectin tablets to treat two infections caused by parasitic worms:</p><ul><li>Strongyloidiasis, which can cause problems like belly <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/default.htm">pain</a>, <a data-crosslink-type="slideshows" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/ss/slideshow-bloating-reasons">bloating</a>, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/heartburn-gerd/default.htm">heartburn</a>, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea">diarrhea</a>, and <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/guide/common-rashes">rashes</a>. However, most people who catch it don’t have symptoms.</li><li>Onchocerciasis, also called river blindness, which can bring on an itchy rash, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes">eye</a> disease, or abnormal growths under the <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/picture-of-the-skin">skin</a>.</li></ul><p>Doctors can also prescribe a type of ivermectin that you put on your skin (called a topical medication) to treat <a data-crosslink-type="slideshows" href="https://www.webmd.com/children/ss/slideshow-lice-overview">head lice</a> and skin conditions like <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/understanding-rosacea-basics">rosacea</a> and <a data-crosslink-type="slideshows" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-scabies-overview">scabies</a>.</p><p>In animals, ivermectin can help prevent heartworm disease and certain <a data-crosslink-type="slideshows" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-pictures-of-parasites">parasites</a>.</p><p>It’s dangerous for humans to take any drug made for animals, including ivermectin. A dose meant for a big animal like a horse or cow (which can weigh 2,000 pounds or more) can be toxic for a person. Also, some of the inactive ingredients in an animal medication might not be safe for people.</p></section><section><h2 id="091e9c5e8222348c-1-3">Is Ivermectin Approved to Treat COVID-19?</h2><p>The FDA hasn’t approved ivermectin to treat or prevent the illness caused by the <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/lung/coronavirus">coronavirus</a>.</p><p>Scientists have been studying the drug to find out if it can treat COVID-19, but they need more information before they can say whether it’s safe or effective. That’s why major groups like the FDA, the Infectious Diseases Society of America, and the World Health Organization say you shouldn’t take ivermectin for COVID-19 unless you’re enrolled in a professional medical study called a <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/clincial-trial-guide-patients">clinical trial</a>.</p><p>The best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the coronavirus is to get vaccinated. The COVID-19 <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/vaccines/covid-19-vaccine/covid-19-vaccine">vaccines</a> are approved for everyone 12 years old and up. They’re generally safe and effective, with the benefits outweighing any risks.</p><p>The same can’t be said about taking ivermectin for COVID-19. If you’re not under a doctor’s care, it’s possible to take too much and <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose">overdose</a>, which can lead to <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics">seizures</a>, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/brain/coma-types-causes-treatments-prognosis">coma</a>, and death.</p></section></div><div class="article-page " data-page="2"><section><h2 id="091e9c5e8222348c-2-4">What Are the Side Effects of Ivermectin?</h2><p>At doses that doctors usually prescribe for people, ivermectin can have side effects like:</p><ul><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-constipation">Constipation</a></li><li>Diarrhea</li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics">Headache</a></li><li>Pain in your joints, muscles, or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach">stomach</a></li><li>Lower appetite</li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting">Nausea</a> or vomiting</li><li>Tenderness in your neck, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/picture-of-the-armpit">armpit</a>, or groin</li><li>Shaky movements (tremors)</li></ul><p>Call your doctor right away if you’re taking prescription ivermectin and notice severe side effects like:</p><ul><li>An <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes">allergic reaction</a> like a rash, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/guide/why-so-itchy">itching</a>, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/guide/skin-conditions-hives-urticaria-angioedema">hives</a>, or swelling of your face, lips, or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/picture-of-the-tongue">tongue</a></li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments">Trouble breathing</a></li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/default.htm">Vision</a> changes</li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/guide/whats-causing-my-chest-pain">Chest pain</a></li><li>Fast, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/heart-disease/guide/what-causes-heart-palpitations">irregular heartbeat</a></li><li>Confusion</li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/eye-pain-causes-symptoms-diagnosis-treatment">Eye pain</a>, redness, or swelling</li><li>Dizziness or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics">fainting</a></li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/lung/what-is-a-fever">Fever</a></li><li>Skin that gets red, <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/understanding-blisters-basics">blisters</a>, peels, or loosens</li><li><a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/types-of-seizures-their-symptoms">Seizures</a></li><li>Peeing or <a data-crosslink-type="tools" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/rm-quiz-poop">pooping</a> that you can’t control</li><li>New swelling</li><li>Unusual tiredness or weakness</li></ul><p> </p></section><section><h2 id="091e9c5e8222348c-2-5">How Do You Take Ivermectin?</h2><p>If your doctor recommends ivermectin tablets to treat a medical issue, make sure they know about any other health conditions you have. It’s especially important to tell them if you:</p><ul><li>Have <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/asthma/default.htm">asthma</a> or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/hepatitis/liver-and-hepatic-diseases">liver disease</a></li><li>Have had unusual or allergic reactions to foods, ingredients, or medicines</li><li>Are <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/baby/default.htm">pregnant</a>, trying to conceive, or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/nursing-basics">breastfeeding</a></li></ul></section><section> <p>Also let them know about any other medications or <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/default.htm">supplements</a> you’re taking. Ivermectin can mix badly with meds like <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood">blood</a>-thinning drugs.</p><p>Carefully follow your doctor’s instructions on how to take ivermectin. Swallow the correct dose with a glass of <a data-crosslink-type="article" href="https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/wonders-of-water">water</a> on an empty <a data-crosslink-type="tools" href="https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/rm-quiz-surprising-stomach-facts">stomach</a> at least 30 minutes before you eat or 2 hours afterward. Don’t take ivermectin with food.</p><p>Take the full course of medicine as prescribed, even if you start feeling better before you finish taking it. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as possible. If it’s almost time for you to take your next dose, take that dose alone; don’t take double the amount.</p></section></div></div><footer style="display:none;"><div class="pub-info-and-share-bar"><div class="article__publication-sources"><span data-e2e="dart-sources" data-chronicle="091e9c5e81e48710" class="sources"><h4 class="sources__header"> Show Sources </h4><div class="sources__wrapper"><p>SOURCES:</p><p>FDA: “Why You Should Not Use Ivermectin to Treat or Prevent COVID-19.”</p><p>Infectious Diseases Society of America: “IDSA Guidelines on the Treatment and Management of Patients with COVID-19.”</p><p>World Health Organization: “WHO advises that ivermectin only be used to treat COVID-19 within clinical trials.”</p><p>Cleveland Clinic: “Ivermectin tablets.”</p><p>CDC: “Strongyloidiasis Infection FAQs,” “Onchocerciasis FAQs,” “Selected Adverse Events Reported after COVID-19 Vaccination.”</p></div></span></div><div class="no-ssr-placeholder"></div></div><span data-chronicle="091e9c5e81e48710" data-e2e="asset-copyright" class="copyright"><!----> © 2021 WebMD, LLC. link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fdrugs\u002F2\u002Fdrug-1122\u002Fivermectin+oral\u002Fdetails\"\u003EIvermectin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" There are two types of the medication. Doctors prescribe one kind for certain health conditions in people, and veterinarians prescribe another that’s safe only for animals.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_text\u003E\u003Chighlights \u002F\u003E\u003Cpull_quotes \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_group\u003E\u003Csection_group\u003E\u003Csection_header\u003EWhat Conditions Does Ivermectin Treat?\u003C\u002Fsection_header\u003E\u003Csection_text\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn people, the FDA has approved prescription ivermectin tablets to treat two infections caused by parasitic worms:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EStrongyloidiasis, which can cause problems like belly \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fpain-management\u002Fdefault.htm\"\u003Epain\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Slideshows\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fdigestive-disorders\u002Fss\u002Fslideshow-bloating-reasons\"\u003Ebloating\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fheartburn-gerd\u002Fdefault.htm\"\u003Eheartburn\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fdigestive-disorders\u002Fdigestive-diseases-diarrhea\"\u003Ediarrhea\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fskin-problems-and-treatments\u002Fguide\u002Fcommon-rashes\"\u003Erashes\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. However, most people who catch it don’t have symptoms.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003Cli\u003EOnchocerciasis, also called river blindness, which can bring on an itchy rash, \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Feye-health\u002Fpicture-of-the-eyes\"\u003Eeye\u003C\u002Fa\u003E disease, or abnormal growths under the \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fskin-problems-and-treatments\u002Fpicture-of-the-skin\"\u003Eskin\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\u003Cp\u003EDoctors can also prescribe a type of ivermectin that you put on your skin (called a topical medication) to treat \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Slideshows\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fchildren\u002Fss\u002Fslideshow-lice-overview\"\u003Ehead lice\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and skin conditions like \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fskin-problems-and-treatments\u002Funderstanding-rosacea-basics\"\u003Erosacea\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Slideshows\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fskin-problems-and-treatments\u002Fss\u002Fslideshow-scabies-overview\"\u003Escabies\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIn animals, ivermectin can help prevent heartworm disease and certain \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Slideshows\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fskin-problems-and-treatments\u002Fss\u002Fslideshow-pictures-of-parasites\"\u003Eparasites\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIt’s dangerous for humans to take any drug made for animals, including ivermectin. A dose meant for a big animal like a horse or cow (which can weigh 2,000 pounds or more) can be toxic for a person. Also, some of the inactive ingredients in an animal medication might not be safe for people.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_text\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_group\u003E\u003Csection_group\u003E\u003Cpagebreak type=\"mobile\" order=\"2\" \u002F\u003E\u003Csection_header\u003EIs Ivermectin Approved to Treat COVID-19?\u003C\u002Fsection_header\u003E\u003Csection_text\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe FDA hasn’t approved ivermectin to treat or prevent the illness caused by the \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Flung\u002Fcoronavirus\"\u003Ecoronavirus\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EScientists have been studying the drug to find out if it can treat COVID-19, but they need more information before they can say whether it’s safe or effective. That’s why major groups like the FDA, the Infectious Diseases Society of America, and the World Health Organization say you shouldn’t take ivermectin for COVID-19 unless you’re enrolled in a professional medical study called a \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fa-to-z-guides\u002Fclincial-trial-guide-patients\"\u003Eclinical trial\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the coronavirus is to get vaccinated. The COVID-19 \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fvaccines\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine\"\u003Evaccines\u003C\u002Fa\u003E are approved for everyone 12 years old and up. They’re generally safe and effective, with the benefits outweighing any risks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003EThe same can’t be said about taking ivermectin for COVID-19. If you’re not under a doctor’s care, it’s possible to take too much and \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fmental-health\u002Faddiction\u002Fdrug-overdose\"\u003Eoverdose\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which can lead to \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fepilepsy\u002Funderstanding-seizures-basics\"\u003Eseizures\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fbrain\u002Fcoma-types-causes-treatments-prognosis\"\u003Ecoma\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and death.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_text\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_group\u003E\u003Csection_group\u003E\u003Cpagebreak type=\"mobile\" order=\"3\" \u002F\u003E\u003Cpagebreak type=\"desktop\" You Take Ivermectin?\u003C\u002Fsection_header\u003E\u003Csection_text\u003E\u003Cp\u003EIf your doctor recommends ivermectin tablets to treat a medical issue, make sure they know about any other health conditions you have. It’s especially important to tell them if you:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cul\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHave \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fasthma\u002Fdefault.htm\"\u003Easthma\u003C\u002Fa\u003E or \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fhepatitis\u002Fliver-and-hepatic-diseases\"\u003Eliver disease\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003Cli\u003EHave had unusual or allergic reactions to foods, ingredients, or medicines\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003Cli\u003EAre \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fbaby\u002Fdefault.htm\"\u003Epregnant\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, trying to conceive, or \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fparenting\u002Fbaby\u002Fnursing-basics\"\u003Ebreastfeeding\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_text\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_group\u003E\u003Csection_group\u003E\u003Cpagebreak type=\"mobile\" order=\"4\" \u002F\u003E\u003Csection_header is_continued=\"true\"\u003EHow Do You Take Ivermectin? continued...\u003C\u002Fsection_header\u003E\u003Csection_text\u003E\u003Cp\u003EAlso let them know about any other medications or \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fvitamins-and-supplements\u002Flifestyle-guide-11\u002Fdefault.htm\"\u003Esupplements\u003C\u002Fa\u003E you’re taking. Ivermectin can mix badly with meds like \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fheart\u002Fanatomy-picture-of-blood\"\u003Eblood\u003C\u002Fa\u003E-thinning drugs.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ECarefully follow your doctor’s instructions on how to take ivermectin. Swallow the correct dose with a glass of \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Article\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fa-to-z-guides\u002Ffeatures\u002Fwonders-of-water\"\u003Ewater\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on an empty \u003Ca crossLinkType=\"Tools\" link_friendlyurl=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.webmd.com\u002Fdigestive-disorders\u002Frm-quiz-surprising-stomach-facts\"\u003Estomach\u003C\u002Fa\u003E at least 30 minutes before you eat or 2 hours afterward. Don’t take ivermectin with food.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003Cp\u003ETake the full course of medicine as prescribed, even if you start feeling better before you finish taking it. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as possible. If it’s almost time for you to take your next dose, take that dose alone; don’t take double the amount.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_text\u003E\u003C\u002Fsection_group\u003E"},"title":"What readabilityObject.title: What Is Ivermectin?
readabilityObject.content:
Ivermectin is a medication that treats some parasitic diseases. There are two types of the medication. Doctors prescribe one kind for certain health conditions in people, and veterinarians prescribe another that’s safe only for animals.

What Conditions Does Ivermectin Treat?

In people, the FDA has approved prescription ivermectin tablets to treat two infections caused by parasitic worms:

  • Strongyloidiasis, which can cause problems like belly pain, bloating, heartburn, diarrhea, and rashes. However, most people who catch it don’t have symptoms.
  • Onchocerciasis, also called river blindness, which can bring on an itchy rash, eye disease, or abnormal growths under the skin.

Doctors can also prescribe a type of ivermectin that you put on your skin (called a topical medication) to treat head lice and skin conditions like rosacea and scabies.

In animals, ivermectin can help prevent heartworm disease and certain parasites.

It’s dangerous for humans to take any drug made for animals, including ivermectin. A dose meant for a big animal like a horse or cow (which can weigh 2,000 pounds or more) can be toxic for a person. Also, some of the inactive ingredients in an animal medication might not be safe for people.

Is Ivermectin Approved to Treat COVID-19?

The FDA hasn’t approved ivermectin to treat or prevent the illness caused by the coronavirus.

Scientists have been studying the drug to find out if it can treat COVID-19, but they need more information before they can say whether it’s safe or effective. That’s why major groups like the FDA, the Infectious Diseases Society of America, and the World Health Organization say you shouldn’t take ivermectin for COVID-19 unless you’re enrolled in a professional medical study called a clinical trial.

The best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the coronavirus is to get vaccinated. The COVID-19 vaccines are approved for everyone 12 years old and up. They’re generally safe and effective, with the benefits outweighing any risks.

The same can’t be said about taking ivermectin for COVID-19. If you’re not under a doctor’s care, it’s possible to take too much and overdose, which can lead to seizures, coma, and death.

What Are the Side Effects of Ivermectin?

At doses that doctors usually prescribe for people, ivermectin can have side effects like:

  • Constipation
  • Diarrhea
  • Headache
  • Pain in your joints, muscles, or stomach
  • Lower appetite
  • Nausea or vomiting
  • Tenderness in your neck, armpit, or groin
  • Shaky movements (tremors)

Call your doctor right away if you’re taking prescription ivermectin and notice severe side effects like:

  • An allergic reaction like a rash, itching, hives, or swelling of your face, lips, or tongue
  • Trouble breathing
  • Vision changes
  • Chest pain
  • Fast, irregular heartbeat
  • Confusion
  • Eye pain, redness, or swelling
  • Dizziness or fainting
  • Fever
  • Skin that gets red, blisters, peels, or loosens
  • Seizures
  • Peeing or pooping that you can’t control
  • New swelling
  • Unusual tiredness or weakness

How Do You Take Ivermectin?

If your doctor recommends ivermectin tablets to treat a medical issue, make sure they know about any other health conditions you have. It’s especially important to tell them if you:

  • Have asthma or liver disease
  • Have had unusual or allergic reactions to foods, ingredients, or medicines
  • Are pregnant, trying to conceive, or breastfeeding

Also let them know about any other medications or supplements you’re taking. Ivermectin can mix badly with meds like blood-thinning drugs.

Carefully follow your doctor’s instructions on how to take ivermectin. Swallow the correct dose with a glass of water on an empty stomach at least 30 minutes before you eat or 2 hours afterward. Don’t take ivermectin with food.

Take the full course of medicine as prescribed, even if you start feeling better before you finish taking it. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as possible. If it’s almost time for you to take your next dose, take that dose alone; don’t take double the amount.
